an3.94:4.1: “After the rainy season the sky is clear and cloudless. And when the sun rises, it dispels all the darkness from the sky as it shines and glows and radiates.
an3.94:5.1: In the same way, when the spotless, immaculate vision of the Dharma arises in a noble disciple, three fetters are given up:
an3.94:5.2: identity view, doubt, and misapprehension of precepts and observances.
an3.94:6.1: Afterwards they get rid of two things: desire and aversion.
an3.94:6.2: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
an3.94:6.3: If that noble disciple passed away at that time, they’re bound by no fetter that might return them to this world.”
